attributes.title: Stock Take
attributes.description: •    Physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread +14 loaves, White flour +11.861 kg, Brown flour -26.443kg, Wheat Bran +5.869 kg, Polybags +3561 pieces. The rest stocks items had minimal variances
attributes.recommendation:
•    Variances in white flour, Brown flour and polybags should be investigated to establish the cause.
•    Controls on finished product should be maintained.
attributes.effect: Weak stock controls leads to variances which could result in to financial loss to the company.

value: •    Flour variance could be as result of BOM for different varieties, we call upon the operation to investigate and the correct adjustment done.
•    We are following on flour variances to establish the cause particularly on BOM and we shall share our recommendations for adjustments.

•    In prior audit on 4th Feb 2025, It was noted that there were zero or minimal variations between the physical and the book stocks in most items except, Poly bags had cumulative variance of +460 pieces, Bread stock had short fall of 97.50 loaves, Wheat Bran which had a variance of -13.53Kg
Current

•    Stock take was conducted on 12th March 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
•    Variances on some stock items is an indication of weak stock controls.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure adequate stock controls are in place to mitigate losses.

attributes.title: Bread Weight
attributes.description: •    From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 400g CT – 31%, 800g W  - 8%, 400g SN - 16%, 400g Barrel - 33%, 600g W – 30%.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch management should ensure correct measures are in place to ensure bread produced meets the correct weight standards.
•    Regular weight spot checks from the divider (dough) to the slicers (packed bread)
attributes.effect: •     Presence of underweight bread is an indication that the company is exposed to financial and reputational risks in form of penalties and customer dissatisfaction respectively.

value: •    Some cases of underweight results from overcooling but we will ensure that slicer are properly supervised to avoid bread overcooling.
•    We shall continue to do random weight check to make sure our workers adhere to the set production standards.
•    In prior audit, underweights were observed across all the varieties sampled as follows; 400 CTW – 33%, 600 CTW – 33%, 800g W – 11%, 1.5kg W – 97%, 400 BW – 25%, 600 BW – 32%, 800 BW – 28%.
Current

•    Bread weight was taken from a sample selected from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to determine whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.
We have cases of underweight bread being dispatched to the market exposing the company to risks of being penalized if caught by weight and measure officials.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure bread produced is of the right weight standards.

attributes.title: Damages analysis
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.27% of the total production and market damages stood at 0.54% of the total sales. 
•    Physical damages weighed compared to Manager’s records had a variance of +13.9kg equivalent to 34.75 loaves.
attributes.recommendation:
•    The branch should strictly adhere to the laid down production procedures to keep damages at the acceptable levels.
•    Damages store should be kept dry to control moulds growth.
attributes.effect: Both production & market damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold exposing the company to a cumulative revenue loss of Kshs. 46,004.

value: Production damages above the set level was caused by oven damages

•    We shall ensure damages as a result of negligence are deducted from the person responsible.
•    We shall ensure damages awaiting collection to ingredients are stored properly.

•    In the previous audit, it was found that production bread damages were averaging at 0.23% (exclusive of oven damages of 693 loaves) of the production damages and market damages stood at 0.77% of the sales.
Current

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for a period of 30 days - 10th Feb 2025 to 11th Mar 2025 to determine whether bread damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales.
•    Both production & market damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that damages are at acceptable levels

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description:
•    The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart analysis

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

•    Yield for 600W as per the BOM is 126. From the mixing charts analysis, it was noted that it is recorded as either 126 or 128. Upon actual confirmation, audit confirmed actual yield for 600W is indeed 128 loaves. Sampled mix was correctly recorded as 128.
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch need to put more effort to achieve the set production target.
•    Yield for 600w should be accurately defined to ensure there is clarity on the expected yield.
•    Supervisors to ensure there is accuracy in actual yield recording.
attributes.effect:
• 89% in target achievement implies that there exist 11% idle capacity.
  • understatement of yield suggest that the company may be losing revenue.

value:
•    Target shortfall is a result of rampant breakdown otherwise our sales exceeds our production
•    BOM yield for 600W is 126, but dividers are advised to record the actual yield.

•    Several break down have contributed to the branch missing the production target.
•    We have arrangement to have a technician to be based in the branch to reduce the response time once there is a break down

•    In the previous audit, it was noted Utto consumption stood at 100 %, Average yield was 190.98 loaves per bag, and Average production was 114.96 bags per day this represent 82.11% of the set target of 140 bags.
•    It was observed that yield for 600 ctw was being understated by 2
Current

•    An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 30 days from 10th Feb 2025 to 11th Mar 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM and if the set production standards were achieved.

•    The branch production capacity was not fully utilised with target achievement at 89%. 
•    Variation in 600 W, actual yield compared to BOM creates room for understatement of the actual yield.
Operations/Production Department
To confirm accuracy of data transferred to cash flow and SAP as well as raw material consumption and production target achievement.

attributes.title: Cash Count
attributes.description: Counted cash compared to cashflow balance had a minimal variance of Kes. +7
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place.
attributes.effect: •    Minimal cash variance implies that effective controls are in place.

value: Well noted
We shall maintain
•    Verification of cash held at the cash office was done on 13th March 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.
Good controls on cash are in place
To ensure adequate cash safeguards are in place

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description: Production efficiency for a 30 day period was 4.19 bags per production worker. Summary of the analysis is shown below;
attributes.recommendation: •    The production workers hired should be managed well to ensure they achieve the set target.
attributes.effect: •    Failure to achieve production target efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker implies the company incurred unbudgeted labour cost

value: •    Break down of machinery and technicians response time slow down production hence affecting the workers efficiency.
•    Plans are in place to have a resident technician at the branch to reduce response time to machine breakdown affecting efficiency.
•    In the prior audit, it was noted that the production efficiency was 4.07 bags per production worker

•    Production efficiency was calculated for a period of 30 days from 10th Feb 2025 to 11th Mar 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
The branch production workers efficiency was below the set standards of 4.5 bags per production worker.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that the company does not incur unbudgeted cost on production labour

attributes.title: Packing efficiency
attributes.description: •    Analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 88.06 crates per slicer.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch management should ensure slicers are hired based on the workload and also they should be pushed to achieve the set efficiency.
attributes.effect: •    Slicing efficiency of 89.69 crates per slicer implies that the company incurred Kshs 36,480 on extra slicers hired

value:
•    The size of our cooling wire affect the slicer speed as it requires two people to carry one wire.
•    We will continue to push packers to reduce the inefficiency.
•    Packing efficiency has been an issue with branch, the branch manager and supervisors have been tasked to ensure workers are pushed to achieve the efficiency.
•    In the prior audit, It was noted that  the average packing efficiency for the sampled period was 76.11 crates
Current
•    Slicing Efficiency was computed for a period of 30 days from 10th February 2025 to 11th March 2025 to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per slicer was being achieved.
Packers hired did not achieve the desired efficiency of 97 crates per slicer.

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description: As of 13th March 2025, the total outstanding debtors amounted to Kshs 1,367,704.30. Institutions and supermarkets balances forms 92% of the total outstanding debts. It was further noted that there were three dormant accounts amounting to Kshs 42,011
attributes.recommendation: •    Follow up on the outstanding balances by the Sales representative for recovery.
attributes.effect: •    Outstanding route balances can lead to bad debts and hence financial losses.

value: Sales Rep to do follow up
Sales rep to follow up on the outstanding balances
Current
•    An analysis of the route balances was done as at 13th March 2025 to ascertain the status thereof.
There exist route balances for customer without credit arrangements
Sales Department
To ensure that there are no route balances for customers without credit arrangement or security deposit.

attributes.title: Vehicle consumption analysis
attributes.description: •    It was noted that most branch vehicles had minimal fuel consumption variances from the set standards except for KCA 850N (Kapsowar route) which had faulty odometer between 8th March and 10th March resulting to inaccurate total kilometers covered.
attributes.recommendation: •    Branch manager should continue to ensure sales vans fuel consumption is within the set standards.
attributes.effect: Fuel consumption within the set standards implies that the company distribution costs are within the budget.

value: •    We will continue to monitor sales vans fuel consumption
•    Fuel consumption is within the set standards.
•    In the prior audit, It was noted that all vehicles fuel consumption were within the set standards.
Current
•    Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st March 2025 to 12th March 2025. To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
•    Fuel consumption is within the set standards which implies adequate controls are in place.
Transport/Fleet Department
To ensure fuel consumption by the sales van is within the set standards.
